hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: Puali‘i was preparing the ko‘ilipi and went to the place where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was found, tearing apart the sweet potato patches, four in total, on the fire. He knew all the children, and they were all gathered at a resting place for Puali‘i. Puali‘i spoke to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Hey! This ko‘ilipi in my hand, it is a man’s food for my head today, and my head, and then, the pig with the sweet potato, and eat me first, then, free.” No one else heard the words of Puali‘i, and then, the words of Puali‘i, the two of them. Puali‘i continued to eat Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s ko‘ilipi, at that time, he prayed to Nāmakaokapāo‘o for his prayer to be made by Puali‘i. Thus the prayer: “Only my eyes of pāo‘o (fish) are dear to me. Let the ripe (fruit) be, let the ripe (fruit) be here. Let the pig be, let the pig be. Let the pig be here, Nākukui‘aimakaokalani. O Kukui‘aimakaokalani is that. O my dear place is this. O Nāmakaokai‘a, the high chief of Hawai‘i. Let the ripe (fruit) be, let the ripe (fruit) be. Only people with the ihe (ritual object), only the ihe with the pahu (ritual vessel). Only Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”
raw_response:
<translation>  
Puali‘i was preparing the ko‘ilipi and went to the place where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was found, tearing apart the sweet potato patches, four in total, on the fire. He knew all the children, and they were all gathered at a resting place for Puali‘i. Puali‘i spoke to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Hey! This ko‘ilipi in my hand, it is a man’s food for my head today, and my head, and then, the pig with the sweet potato, and eat me first, then, free.” No one else heard the words of Puali‘i, and then, the words of Puali‘i, the two of them. Puali‘i continued to eat Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s ko‘ilipi, at that time, he prayed to Nāmakaokapāo‘o for his prayer to be made by Puali‘i. Thus the prayer: “Only my eyes of pāo‘o (fish) are dear to me. Let the ripe (fruit) be, let the ripe (fruit) be here. Let the pig be, let the pig be. Let the pig be here, Nākukui‘aimakaokalani. O Kukui‘aimakaokalani is that. O my dear place is this. O Nāmakaokai‘a, the high chief of Hawai‘i. Let the ripe (fruit) be, let the ripe (fruit) be. Only people with the ihe (ritual object), only the ihe with the pahu (ritual vessel). Only Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
**Paragraph 7:**  
• This passage describes a ritualistic act of Puali‘i consuming ko‘ilipi (a type of fish or symbolic offering) and engaging in a prayer to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, reflecting the **'Ai Kapu era** (sacred eating period) where offerings and prayers were central to maintaining spiritual balance and ensuring prosperity;  
– **Ko‘ilipi** (ko‘ilipi): A fish species, possibly linked to **'Ai Kapu** practices where specific foods were offered to gods. Its destruction by Nāmakaokapāo‘o may symbolize a challenge to traditional rituals;  
– **Nāmakaokapāo‘o** (Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o): The name translates to “the eyes of the pāo‘o fish” (pāo‘o meaning “fish” or “a fish’s head,” with **maka** (eyes) as a poetic metaphor. This ties to the **'Ai Kapu** tradition, where symbolic substitutions like **ulua** (fish) replaced human sacrifices;  
• The phrase “tearing apart the sweet potato patches, four in all, on the fire” highlights **agricultural symbolism** and the **destruction of sacred resources**, which could allegorically represent the **abandonment of 'Ai Kapu restrictions** or the **defiance of cultural taboos**;  
– **‘Au ‘uala** (sweet potato): A staple crop in Hawaiian society, often central to rituals. Its “tearing apart” may signify **wastefulness** or **rejection of traditional agricultural practices**;  
– **Four (āna ‘ehā)**: A numerical symbol in Hawaiian lore, often representing **completeness** or **sacred cycles**, but here it may underscore the **magnitude of Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s destructive actions**;  
• The prayer structure mirrors **traditional Hawaiian oli (chant)** or **kīoleo (incantation)**, where invocations to deities or ancestors were used to seek protection, abundance, or legitimacy;  
– **“Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o”**: A plea for **protection of the pāo‘o fish’s eyes**, possibly symbolizing **sacred knowledge** or **spiritual insight**;  
– **“E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei”**: A call for **ripeness** and **harvest**, reflecting the **agricultural cycle** and the importance of **seasonal rituals**;  
– **“E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha”**: Repeated invocations for **sacrificial offerings** (pigs, sweet potatoes), aligning with **'Ai Kapu** practices where animals and crops were offered to gods;  
• The names **Nākukui‘aimakaokalani**, **Kukui‘aimakaokalani**, and **Nāmakaokai‘a** (high chief of Hawai‘i) suggest **genealogical ties** to deities or ancestors, reinforcing the **sacred authority** of Puali‘i’s actions;  
– **Kukui** (light, guide): A name often associated with **ancestral deities** (e.g., Kukui, the god of light). **Aimakaokalani** (ai-maka-o-ka-lani): “the eyes of the sky” or “the eyes of the heavens,” possibly symbolizing **divine vision** or **celestial connection**;  
– **Nākukui** (nā-ku-mui): “the light of the sky” or “the sacred light,” emphasizing **spiritual power** in the prayer;  
• The repetition of “e he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale” (let the ripe be, let the ripe be) reflects **ritualistic formulae** used to **sanctify offerings** or **invoke abundance**, a common feature in **Hawaiian religious practices**;  
– **“Ihe”** (ritual object) and **“pahu”** (ritual vessel) may refer to **sacred tools** used in **'Ai Kapu ceremonies**, where offerings were prepared and presented;  
• The final line “Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o” (Only Nāmakaokapāo‘o) underscores the **exclusive focus on Nāmakaokapāo‘o** as the central figure, possibly symbolizing **the rejection of other deities or practices** in favor of his authority or legacy.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
